Histone methyltransferase SET and MYND Domain Containing 3 (Smyd3) is strongly associated with metabolic and cardiovascular diseases, however, its role in adaptive thermogenesis has not been well characterized. Here, we demonstrate that Smyd3 is abundant and closely involved in adipocyte thermogenic programming. However, genetic ablation of Smyd3 or pharmacological inhibition with the specific inhibitor EPZ031686 robustly enhanced adaptive thermogenesis in mice. Conversely, Smyd3 overexpression attenuated white adipose tissue (WAT) browning both in vivo and in vitro. In this study, we identified histone methyltransferase Smyd3 restrains WAT browning and adaptive thermogenesis by inhibiting PPARγ expression in a H4K20me3-dependent manner. Deletion or inhibition of Smyd3 triggers the thermogenic program, which may be a potential target for therapeutics of obesity and the related disorders. A notable discrepancy exists between the expression profile of Smyd3 and its functional roles in thermogenic adipocyte regulation, presenting an intriguing paradox that warrants further investigation. Notably, Smyd3 showed enrichment in BAT and iWAT, with its expression being substantially upregulated following cold exposure (4 °C) and β3-adrenergic receptor agonist CL316,243 stimulation. However, our in vitro and in vivo data show that Smyd3 exerts a suppressive effect on WAT browning or adaptive thermogenesis. Animal experiments All laboratory animal procedures were in accordance with the Guide for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals (8th edition 2011) issued by the National Institutes of Health and were approved by the Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) of Fudan University. Mice were fed and watered AD libitum at room temperature 22–23 °C and humidity 40–60% under a 12-h light/dark cycle. Male mice were selected due to variables in female mice (uncertain hormonal changes, etc.). Mice were sacrificed by intraperitoneal injection of pentobarbital (150 mg/kg). Adipose tissue was then harvested for further examination. For the Smyd3 specific inhibitor EPZ031686 treatments, EPZ031686 (20 mg/kg) was intraperitoneally injected daily for a week. Then mice were sacrificed and adipose tissues were obtained as described above. For the mice adaptive thermogenesis model, CL316,243 (0.5 mg/kg) was intraperitoneally injected daily for a week. Histological analysis of adipose tissues The BAT, iWAT, and eWAT samples were fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde solution. Paraffin sections of 5 μm thickness were prepared and stained with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E). Images shown in figures are representative results of at least four biological replicates. Adipocyte sizes were analyzed by ImageJ software. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) BAT, iWAT, and eWAT were fixed with fat fixation solution and sectioned into 5 μm paraffin sections. Subsequently, antigen retrieval was performed, and non-specific binding sites were blocked with 10% goat serum. The sections were incubated with primary antibodies overnight at 4 °C and then with secondary antibodies. Signal was detected using DAB staining, followed by hematoxylin counterstaining. The target protein expression was assessed via microscopic observation and image analysis. Positive cell counts for quantifying the target protein were performed using ImageJ software. Culture and differentiation of primary stroma-vascular fraction (SVF) cells The primary SVF cells derived from iWAT and BAT of male mice were isolated according to previously established protocols [ 32 2 Culture and browning induction of 3T3-L1 preadipocytes The 3T3-L1 preadipocytes were cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS and 1% penicillin-streptomycin until reaching confluence. Subsequently, the 3T3-L1 cells were induced with induction medium containing DMEM, 10% FBS, 10 µg/ml insulin, 0.5 mM IBMX, 1 µM rosiglitazone, 1 µM T3, and 1 µM dexamethasone (day 0). Two days later, the cells were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS, 1 µM T3, 1 µM rosiglitazone, and 10 µg/ml insulin (day 2), and the same treatment was repeated on day 4. Following an additional two days, the cells were stimulated in DMEM containing 10% FBS and 1 µM CL316,243 and maintained in this medium until complete differentiation. The medium was changed every two days. Small interfering RNA (siRNA) transfection The mouse Smyd3 siRNA (sense 5’- CGGGAAUGCAGUUGUCUUATT-3’, antisense 5’-UAAGACAACUGCAUUCCCGTT-3’) and control siRNA (5’-UUCUCCGAACGUGUCACGUTT-3’) were procured from GenePharma (Shanghai, China) and transfected into either 3T3-L1 preadipocytes or iWAT-SVF cells using Lipofectamine RNAiMAX transfection reagent (Invitrogen), following the manufacturer’s protocol. Following transfection for 24 h, the medium was replaced with fresh serum-containing medium, and the cells were then induced for differentiation. Western blotting After being lysed with RIPA lysis buffer (Servicebio, China) containing protease inhibitors to mitigate protein degradation, the harvested adipose tissues or cells were subjected to examine the protein concentration using a BCA assay kit (Share-bio). Subsequently, the protein samples were separated by SDS-PAGE and transferred onto nitrocellulose (NC) membranes. Following a 1.5 h blocking step at room temperature, the membranes were incubated with the corresponding primary antibodies overnight at 4 °C. The next day, anti-rabbit or anti-mouse IgG HRP-conjugated secondary antibodies were applied, after which the experimental results were detected using ChemiDoc + Real-Time quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) analysis Total RNA was extracted from adipose tissues or cells using TRIzol Reagent (TaKaRa Biotechnology, Dalian, China). Subsequently, 2 µg of RNA underwent DNA digestion and reverse transcription using a PrimeScript 1st Strand cDNA Synthesis Kit (Takara). Quantitative real-time PCR (qPCR) analysis of the target mRNA levels was conducted using the iCycler iQ system (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA, USA) with SYBR Green, and the expression was normalized to β-actin.
